I want to ask again like before in https://github.com/groovy/groovy-eclipse/issues/1353: Is this going to be back-ported to Groovy 2.5.x where I detected it? Thank you in advance for your reply.

@kriegaex I'm considering the risk of moving the changes back to Groovy 3 and 2.5.  There is a small difference in map property access that could catch people off guard.  It needs to be an object that implements both the `GroovyObject` and `Map` interfaces, so it is not widespread.  But there have been several issues filed over time for such cases, so it does exist in the wild.
Is this the same way `Verifier` handles it for normal methods?
FWIW, ASM 9.3 with Java 19 support was released yesterday.
Merged. Thanks!

This is a little strange. We don't have separate LICENSE files in general in each subproject since the main LICENSE file covers all subprojects. The LICENSE is embedded into the respective jars during assembly[1]. The BOM artifact has no jar, just a pom which contains among other things the following excerpt:
```
<licenses>
  <license>
    <name>The Apache Software License, Version 2.0</name>
    <url>http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0.txt</url>
    <distribution>repo</distribution>
  </license>
</licenses>
```
We'll need to examine what `:checkLicense` is expecting.

[1] https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/master/build.gradle#L192

> FWIW, ASM 9.3 with Java 19 support was released yesterday.

Yes, I got the release e-mail, too. But without encouragement by @eric-milles or another project maintainer here, I would rather not extend the PR to encompass ASM 9.3 and Java 19 yet, because Eric was already skeptical about 9.2 and e.g. did not merge the PR before the 2.5.16 release. Maybe 2.5.17? I am not sure. But of course, I could easily bump to 9.3, not expecting any incompatibilities. The tests remained green without any changes after the bump to 9.2, too. So I am waiting for feedback.

It looks like it would be safe (and in fact desirable) for you to set the `:checkLicense` `excludeBoms` property to true.
The relevant code is here:
https://github.com/jk1/Gradle-License-Report/blob/master/src/main/groovy/com/github/jk1/license/LicenseReportExtension.groovy#L97
So, if I understand correctly, it will not try to check boms if there is no jar artifact.
This has been simplified to be more like Verifier. I think there is still scope for catering for additional subexpressions but we can cover that in future changes.
I'll close this based on my earlier comments. If you don't agree, let's discuss further.
As per comments in the associated issue, we will try a different approach here.
Sounds like a reasonable fix

@eric-milles When the codenarcMain task is run, there are stack traces like below:
```
Error from [org.codenarc.rule.naming.ClassNameRule] processing source file [D:/projects/groovyCopy/subprojects/groovy-ant/src/main/groovy/groovy/ant/FileNameFinder.groovy]
groovy.lang.MissingMethodException: No signature of method: org.codenarc.rule.naming.AbstractTypeNameAstVisitor.visitClassEx() is applicable for argument types: (org.codehaus.groovy.ast.ClassNode) values: [groovy.ant.FileNameFinder]
Possible solutions: visitClassEx(org.codehaus.groovy.ast.ClassNode), visitClass(org.codehaus.groovy.ast.ClassNode), visitClass(org.codehaus.groovy.ast.ClassNode)
        at org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.ScriptBytecodeAdapter.unwrap(ScriptBytecodeAdapter.java:72)
        at org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.ScriptBytecodeAdapter.invokeMethodOnSuperN(ScriptBytecodeAdapter.java:148)
        at org.codenarc.rule.naming.AbstractTypeNameAstVisitor.visitClassEx(AbstractTypeNameAstVisitor.groovy:44)
        at org.codenarc.rule.AbstractAstVisitor.visitClass(AbstractAstVisitor.java:131)
```
Does that look like GROOVY-10302 to you? I haven't started to debug as yet. It might also be a classloader issue.

Relevant code is here:
https://github.com/CodeNarc/CodeNarc/blob/master/src/main/groovy/org/codenarc/rule/naming/AbstractTypeNameAstVisitor.groovy#L44

`AbstractTypeNameAstVisitor` or `visitClassEx` should be tagged `@CompileStatic` if the intent is to use it across major Groovy versions.  The changes to super method indexing in `MetaClassImpl` can cause problems for old `ScriptBytecodeAdapted.invokeMethodOnSuper` call sites.

Yes, for our use of CodeNarc, the following changes are required:
https://github.com/CodeNarc/CodeNarc/pull/707
There might be more rules we don't use that also need a change.
I'll close this for now.

Need to fix some bad commits.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3310939/174696532-f44de236-295a-4937-bcd1-65e1144d772e.png)

I quite like the idea. I also played around with putting the path in the frame title instead of the label:
```
frame = swing.frame(title: "Groovy Object Browser: $path", location: [200, 200],
```
I am unsure which I prefer. It is visually cleaner in the title I think but does become truncated more quickly.

I think there is more room on the label. But it will eventually get truncated. I could make it wrap, but will have to put maxsize on label to make it wrap. It could be shown at the bottom (SOUTH) of the frame and there use a not-editable textField (will allow copy of the path).

Something like this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3310939/174841212-e5821bf2-92a6-42ea-82dc-cecd0ffe05ca.png)

The user can select the path from the non-editable text field.

Also, I am proposing to close the current ObjectBrowser if CTRL key was down when double-clicked and open the next one to prevent the proliferation of frames.

If you like that I can commit as two separate commits as we can pick and choose.

I went ahead and submitted the two commits.  I used Alt-Double-Click instead o Ctrl-Double-Click because the Ctrl key is also used for extending the selection. Please pick and choose those that make sense.
Looks good - merged!

Merged, thanks! I created this issue to track the details: GROOVY-10665.

You can also do this now, but I don't think it is an improvement over `optional.map(String::length).orElse(null)` or `optional.orElse(null)?.length()`:
```groovy
def nothing = Optional.empty(), something = Optional.of('foo')
def value = nothing*.length()?[0]
assert value == null
value = something*.length()?[0]
assert value == 3
```

And this kind of thing is not supported without `getAt(int)`:
```groovy
def opt = Optional.of('')
def (String x) = opt
assert x == ''
```

Update: https://github.com/apache/groovy/commit/a0de382914b3c6a1e777c4607e8b7edd1e70608e
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-10666 discusses the possibility of supporting multiple-assignment for streams via `getAt(IntRange)`

@paulk-asert I agree, it seems the extension method `Optional<T> collect(Optional<S>,Closure<T>)` is not that valuable.  If deprecated, it would not resolve as an extension, which would then cause `List<T> collect(Object,Closure<T>)` to be selected instead.  I doubt any code that makes use of this is prepared for a list return value.

> @paulk-asert I agree, it seems the extension method `Optional<T> collect(Optional<S>,Closure<T>)` is not that valuable. If deprecated, it would not resolve as an extension, which would then cause `List<T> collect(Object,Closure<T>)` to be selected instead. I doubt any code that makes use of this is prepared for a list return value.

Yes, it would be a breaking change. We'd deprecate it now in Groovy 4 and remove in Groovy 5 with explanation in release notes. Folks wanting to prepare could potentially test with -Dgroovy.extension.disable=collect but that isn't very selective.
We can explain the behavior either way, I just think the explanation is much simpler if it behaves like all the other fallback variants.
Merged. Thanks!

We would not likely include indentation recommendations in this document. Groovy as a language, like Java, is somewhat whitespace agnostic, i.e. it supports multiple indentation practices including 4 spaces, 2 spaces, tabs etc.
The Groovy source code itself mostly follows the 4 space guideline and its not a bad one to follow but this document is mostly about style changes a Java developer might make when moving to Groovy. With that in mind, a developer coming to Groovy can continue whatever whitespace conventions they might already be using in Java.
Merged, thanks!

This leads to the Groovy community applying indention inconsistently.
Developers are free to indent however they see fit, however I think it would serve the Groovy community well to have the recommended indention specified in the style guide. It would make the code style more homogeneous which I think the Groovy developer community would appreciate.

Sometimes consistency is nice, sometimes inclusivity is nice.
OO vs functional style, dynamic vs static, tabs vs spaces.
As a general rule Groovy tries to be agnostic.
For those who want additional consistency there are IDE features and tools like CodeNarc which can be utilised:
https://codenarc.org/codenarc-rules-formatting.html#indentation-rule
(The linked rule checks by default for 4 spaces and other rules can also check brace positioning, line length and spacing and numerous other parameters.)
The nice thing with a style guide is that it is just a guide, not rules. so even with indention defined in the style guide developers would still be free to use whatever they want.
I may yet change `Tuple2<Object, List<String>>` to just `List<?>`.

The tooltip stuff looks great. I am wondering whether a simple right-click => "copy cell" popup menu might be more consistent since we have such actions in other places. Thoughts? Let me know if you want to look into that or want me to play at my end.

Updated to support duck-typing scenario.  I'm still trying to figure how to support 6790, 8142 and `(x instanceof Map || x instanceof List) ? x.size() : 1` at the same time.

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-6790
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-8142
STC still does not produce an error for `o instanceof Map || o instanceof List ? o.entrySet() : null` -- this is not a new issue.

Another thing that surprised me is that LUB(Integer,Double) is Double, not Number.  I'm not sure why this is the case: https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/master/src/main/java/org/codehaus/groovy/ast/tools/WideningCategories.java#L349

This was first added in commit e08c389d67809a421f4f33c27012c54294f98259.  I understand the need for type promotion of primitive types, but there seems to be a conflict with boxed types.  The 8965 test case fails with CCE now when integer is passed.

Thanks. I like the use of the popup menu better. I do not know SwingBuilder very well and could not figure out how to set up the popup menu on the table. If you are familiar and have time please go ahead and implement that. If not, I will look at it next weekend. Do not want to push more work on you though.

The tooltip part of the PR has been merged. Thanks!
I'll try to have a look at the popup menu idea in the next few days.

> Another thing that surprised me is that LUB(Integer,Double) is Double, not Number. I'm not sure why this is the case: https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/master/src/main/java/org/codehaus/groovy/ast/tools/WideningCategories.java#L349
 
WideningCategories was initially for assignment and in some cases compares. Like: you can assign an Integer to a Double, but you cannot assign a Double to an Integer. I highly doubt this will give you the right results for the instanceof|| problem
Merged. Thanks!

With the addition of `getAt(Map,String)` a small change in `StaticTypeCheckingSupport#getDistance` can resolve the `map["$key"]` issues.  I know Cedric stated in 6668 that this should be an STC error, but if there is just one method and it accepts String, it will be chosen for a GString argument.  This change just closes the distance between GString and String so that `m(String)` is selected over `m(Object)`.  Yes, this puts `Map#get` and `Map#getAt` out of alignment for GString arguments, which was a stated concern.  So I can understand if this is rejected in order to keep map access consistent.

`InvocationWriter#loadArguments` already has significant checking/handling for variadic situations.  And `null` is supposed to represent the array, not an array with one `null` element.  I think the safe advice is to use `@CompileStatic` if you have a scenario that passes a single nullable argument for the array parameter and you don't want to wrap in your code.
Merged. Thanks!
